Single crystal is the most useful state to analyze the strucÂ­
ture and physical properties of materials. 2D singleÂ­crystalline
perovskites have been synthesized by a variety of solution

together to start the crystal growth, and later cooling them to
room temperature at a certain cooling rate to quench the furÂ­
ther growth; (mixed) solvent evaporation is similar to the
liquidÂ­phase crystallization. The single crystals are obtained by
evaporating solvent(s) at a relatively slow rate, while the solvent
evaporation can be accelerated by adding another solvent; the
layered solution method involves dissolving the two reactants
in two solvents with certain mutual solubility, and the two soluÂ­
tions have obvious density difference, so as to form a clear interÂ­
face between the two solutions due to the different solubility
and density. With a slow diffusion, largeÂ­sized single crystal
is precipitated at the interface. These solution methods have
some advantages of stability, low cost, and easy operation. The
main solutionÂ­processed methods for synthesizing 2D organicâ
inorganic hybrid perovskites are summarized in

tural guides to regulate the interlayer spacing among inorganic

In 1996, Mitzi reported the synthesis of BA
1, 2, 3, 4) by liquidÂ­phase crystallization. After adding neuÂ­
tralized base BA into the hot aqueous solution containing HI,
, and PbO, followed by a cooling process, the colorful recÂ­
tangular shape sheets started to crystallize and the color changed
from red to black (Figure 2i). The crystallization was completed
2 h later. BA is essential to guide the reaction for accurate conÂ­
perovskite by slowly evaporating the acetone solvent.
